The 209 static findings are almost entirely false positives triggered by documentation patterns (code blocks in markdown) rather than executable code. The setup script validates local Playwright installation using standard dev tooling patterns. No credential theft, data exfiltration, or malicious patterns detected.

content.value_statement: Writing reliable end-to-end tests is challenging without proper guidance. This skill provides expert-level Playwright knowledge including locators, page objects, fixtures, and debugging techniques to help you build robust browser automation tests.
actual_capabilities: Create Playwright test configurations with projects, browsers, and reporters
Write resilient tests using role-based locators and chaining patterns
Implement the Page Object Model with reusable, maintainable page classes
Mock API responses and test error scenarios with network interception
Debug tests using traces, screenshots, and the Playwright Inspector
Set up authentication with storage state and custom test fixtures
limitations: Does not execute tests directly - provides guidance for test creation
Does not install Playwright browsers or dependencies automatically
Requires existing Playwright project structure for best results
Cannot modify existing test files - only provides recommendations

use_cases.title: Build E2E test suites
use_cases.description: Create comprehensive end-to-end test suites using Playwright best practices for selectors, assertions, and test organization.

use_cases.title: Test web applications
use_cases.description: Write reliable browser automation tests for web applications including form testing, API mocking, and visual regression checks.

use_cases.title: Scale test coverage
use_cases.description: Set up cross-browser testing, parallel execution, and CI/CD integration for production-quality test pipelines.

prompt_templates.title: Get started with Playwright
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write my first Playwright test. I want to test a login form with email and password fields and a submit button.

prompt_templates.title: Improve test selectors
prompt_templates.prompt: My Playwright tests are failing because elements cannot be found. Show me how to use role-based locators instead of CSS selectors for better reliability.

prompt_templates.title: Create page objects
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to refactor my Playwright tests to use the Page Object Model. I have tests for login, dashboard, and user profile pages.

prompt_templates.title: Mock API responses
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I mock API responses in Playwright to test error handling, slow networks, and different data scenarios without a real backend?

output_examples.input: Help me write a Playwright test for a contact form with name, email, and message fields
output: Here is a Playwright test for your contact form:
Uses role-based locators for form fields and submit button
Follows Arrange-Act-Assert pattern for clarity
Includes proper assertions for success message
Uses fill() for fast input instead of type()
Test structure:
- beforeEach: Navigate to contact page
- Main test: Fill fields, submit, verify success message

output_examples.input: How do I organize my tests for a large application with many pages
output: Use the Page Object Model pattern:
Create a base page class with common functionality
Each page gets its own class with locators and actions
Keep tests clean by calling page methods, not interacting directly
Benefits:
- Locators defined in one place
- Easy to update when UI changes
- Tests remain readable and maintainable

output_examples.input: My tests are slow because they log in every time. How can I speed this up
output: Use storage state to reuse authentication:
Create an auth.setup.ts that logs in once and saves state
Configure projects in playwright.config.ts to use saved state
Benefits:
- Login runs once instead of per test
- Tests start faster with pre-saved cookies
- Still tests authenticated flows correctly

best_practices: Use role-based locators (getByRole, getByLabel) instead of CSS selectors for accessible, resilient tests
Prefer auto-waiting assertions over explicit waits to avoid flaky tests
Organize tests with Page Objects to separate page logic from test assertions
anti_patterns: Using CSS selectors with nth-child or index-based positioning - breaks when UI changes
Using waitForLoadState('networkidle') - unreliable with WebSockets and analytics
Writing tests without proper assertions - always verify expected outcomes
Hardcoding credentials in tests - use environment variables and storage state instead

faq.question: What Playwright versions are supported?
faq.answer: This skill covers Playwright 1.0+ features. Role-based locators require 1.27+. Run npx playwright --version to check.

faq.question: How many tests can I run in parallel?
faq.answer: Set workers in playwright.config.ts. Use fullyParallel: true for maximum speed. Consider browser limitations.

faq.question: Can I use this with other testing frameworks?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on @playwright/test. For Jest or Vitest, use Playwright as a library rather than the test runner.

faq.question: Is my test data safe?
faq.answer: The skill only reads and provides guidance. It does not store or transmit test data. Use storageState for authentication.

faq.question: Why are my tests flaky?
faq.answer: Common causes: using networkidle, missing assertions, dynamic content not awaited, or element state changes.

faq.question: How does this compare to Selenium?
faq.answer: Playwright offers auto-waiting, built-in assertions, better locators, and faster execution. No external driver needed.
